26059124.review: It's a fun little game. I enjoyed it and would recommend it to others. It's easily worth the 8€ and I would in all likelihood buy a sequal.

26058368.review:
Acabada mi primera partida tras casi 4 horas de juego, aquí va mi pequeño granito de arena para recomendar este juego a los usuarios de habla hispana de STEAM. Pre-Civilization Egypt es uno de esos títulos que no pueden faltar en la estantería digital de cualquier amante de la estrategia, y sobre todo de un amante de la historia, y del antiguo Egipto en particular, pues es en este aspecto donde el título está cuidado al detalle. 

El trasfondo del juego gira en torno a los esfuerzos que tendrás que realizar para conseguir que una tribu nómada instalada en la ribera del río Nilo termine convirtiéndose en uno de los principales proto-estados del período pre-dinástico desde donde parta el esfuerzo unificador del Alto y Bajo Egipto que inició el período de los faraones. No estamos hablando, por tanto, de un juego que se desarrolla en el Egipto que la mayoría de gente conoce, el de su plenitud como civilización, sino  que se centra en los orígenes del mismo. Este trasfondo, en mi opinión, le otorga al título de un mayor interés.

La mecánica del juego es simple, pero a la vez guarda una complejidad interesante. Su simplicidad nace de su modo de juego, tipo tablero y basado en turnos (TBS), donde tendremos que gestionar los recursos disponibles en las distintas casillas del tablero mediante mano de obra. Ahora bien, la complejidad antes mencionada nace en el desarrollo de la partida, cuando nos damos cuenta que, poco a poco, las decisiones que tomamos tienen que estar enfocadas a intentar conseguir los “resultados históricos” que la partida nos va presentando. Así, te das cuenta que para ganar la partida tendrás que utilizar todas las opciones que tengas disponibles, sin maximificar unas en detenimiento de otras. De nada te servirá, por ejemplo, centrar tus esfuerzos en un campo concreto descuidando los otros, porque en unos turnos posteriores verás cómo la decisión que tomaste de centrar tus esfuerzos en conseguir x recurso te han debilitado en otro aspecto, lo que te lleva a no conseguir los objetivos con los que el juego te reta.

Este planteamiento, tiene sus pros y sus contras. Por un lado, hace difícil conseguir una victoria total centrándote en un tipo de estrategia (por ejemplo, usando un enfoque militarista expansionista clásico, basado en atacar a todo bicho viviente del mapa de campaña), lo que más dinamismo en el planteamiento de estrategias. Ahora bien, al existir la cuestión de los “resultados históricos” hace que la aproximación a cualquier partida acabe desarrollándose de forma lineal, pues la gran mayoría de eventos importantes o evolución de la tribu se desarrolla siempre de la misma forma, y no hay posibilidad de cambiarlo. Vamos, tienes que ir de A hacia D, y sabes que entre una letra y otra hay inequívocamente B y C. La gracia, sin embargo, se encuentra en saber conseguir la forma más eficiente de llegar al final de un camino ya marcado, de ahí que los desarrolladores hayan marcado un sistema de puntuación de 0 a 35 puntos que se otorgan al final de la partida según los objetivos cumplidos y la forma de conseguirlos (en mi caso, en mi primera partida he conseguido la friolera de 3/35 puntos). Intentar mejorar el enfoque de nuestras partidas para así conseguir más puntuación al final, es el caramelo que los desarrolladores han dejado para intentar garantizar una cierta rejugabilidad.

Entiendo, sin embargo, que este modo de juego tenga sus defensores y sus detractores. En mi caso, no me parece mal la mecánica, aunque sí que es cierto que esta “falta de libertad” pueda resultar frustrante en según qué compases del juego.

Saliendo de este tema, y centrándonos en aspectos técnicos y contextuales, el juego es una delicia. Visualmente es precioso, y se aprecia en los detalles de ilustraciones dibujadas a mano, o en las fichas de trabajadores que simulan, por así decirlo, representaciones pictóricas de arte del antiguo egipcio. La música y efectos de sonido son magníficos, y consiguen el efecto de introducirte en el juego aunque tenga gráficos “simples”. En resumen: entra como un guante por los ojos y los oídos a aquellas personas que buscan una experiencia de juego tranquila y relajada.
Quizás, sin embargo, es en el aspecto histórico donde el juego destaca como en ningún otro. La profusión de detalles históricos “reales”(que aparecen en la historiografía, vamos) con los eventos fijos que te guían en la partida, así como los aleatorios, y los pequeños detalles que surgen de vez en cuando (nombres, ciudades, evolución de la religiosidad y los cultos…), hacen que el título sea un verdadero documental sobre el período en el que se centra. Cuando uno termina una partida, creo que se puede hacer una idea más o menos general, de cómo consiguió desarrollarse en aquella región una cultura tan interesante y peculiar como fue la del antiguo Egipto.

Por tanto, y en resumen, el juego vale bien sus 8 € que cuesta. No pretende ser un gran título de estrategia que te robe eones de tu tiempo libre, sino un juego que pretende mostrarte, mediante una mecánica entretenida, un período histórico fascinante. Posiblemente muchos lo guarden en su estantería digital una vez completada su primera partida. Otros le darán otra oportunidad para probar distintos enfoques. En todo caso, está claro que la mayoría pasaréis un buen rato con él, que bien puede valer el precio invertido.

26056998.review:
A relaxing turn-by-turn strategy/puzzle game about resource management. Each play-through runs into the same major events, but there are minor events that mix it up a bit. Knowing the major events coming up is part of the gameplay, so it doesn't really feel unreplayable.

For some reason it reminds me about the 12 Tasks of Hercules series, though it plays nothing like those games. Probably because, at it's core, it is about resource management.

It's got an original slant, it's atmospheric, and I'd love to see more of these.

UPDATE: And now that I'm a bit further along in played hours, I find it kind've relaxing. A bit like playing solitaire: you know what the tasks are, but how you get there is the trick, and no one game is going to knock your socks off.

26056039.review:
The game mechanincs is very similar to Sid Meier's Civilization, and is focused on the historical events that lead to the rise of the Egyptian unified empire. I recommend this game because I had fun playing it, and also because of it's historical accuracy. After playing Egypt Pre-civilization, the player will have an understanding of the events and factors responsible for the development of the ancient Egyptian civilization that would be otherwise difficult or boring to many people to obtain by just reading books and academic papers. I think Egypt Pre-civilization is an example of how video games are an excelent tool to teach knowledge of the real world.

This game is for you if:

* You like Sid Meier's Civilization
* You are interested in ancient Egypt or ancient history

This game is not for you if:

* You are looking for a game as good or better than Sid Meier's Civilization
* You're not interested in Egyptian history at all

Other factors that can drive away people from this game is that is very linear, following the sequence of events that lead to the unification of the Egyptian empire, and that it may be very difficult to win. But again, these drawbacks are otherwise contributing to achieve perhaps the mean goal of the game: teach ancient Egyptian history. On the other hand, I really liked the art design, it's beautiful and captures very well the character of Egyptian art.

26054181.review:
This game offers a very rich historical gaming experience and oh boy does it deliver!


It's an educational linear turn-based historical simulation strategy that will lead you through the history of Ancient Egypt. Starting from 5000 B.C. you will guide the nomadic and humble Egyptian tribe through all the hardships to prosperity and power culminating in the Unification of Lower and Upper Egypt. Get ready to witness evolutionary breakthroughs that enabled early Egyptians to march into faraway lands, fight catastrophes, hardships and ultimately establish first Egyptian state. Will you be able to re-enact the events that unfolded historically or will you doom your fledgling chiefdom into forgotten annals of history? Get an intimate knowledge about events that took place before the Classic Egypt eras through this unique game.


This game really made me understand the evolution of the Egyptian civilization. It all makes so much sense now! It really made me understand the whole history of the area much more. This is such an interesting chapter of the human history and developers have done an amazing job at portraying first steps of the human civilizational evolution in Egypt! 

I really like the ambient of the game, background music, voices, the way upgrades are applied on the map, the way your tribe evolves from meager beginnings to a powerful state, the paintings that are shown when a major event happens, etc. There is a lot of replayability in it too because there's always a new strategy you would like to try out to better the results and maybe delve into higher difficulties and see how your strategic wisdom (or it's lack) will bode for the people you guide.   

The game is not too simple and not too hard, it does stuff very nicely. It is rather unique in what it does. At the release the game did end rather abruptly and the unification warning did not trigger soon enough to warn the player. Wasn't able to complete it because the game didn't provide me with enough information. This has been resolved in the patch now.  

My expectations for this game were fulfilled, love playing it. I usually wait for the game to get discounted but after I tried the demo I couldn't wait and immediately bought it.  

I did more re-runs on higher difficulties. When modding tools get introduced for it more gaming will be squeezed out of it.  


I would recommend the game especially now that it got patched.  

I rate the game on 5-point scale:

Music and sounds 5
Gameplay 4
Graphics 5
Historical accuracy 5

26037912.review: I've played the game since they gave me a demo in a greenlight phase.Even then I knew that game had great potencial.If you like history of Egypt and history itself you will like this game.When you start It is it looks like it is a easy going casual game(so I tought in the beggining).But after playing a while your decisions on the start can cost in middle and in my case in the last two turns.So started again I thought it would be easier the second time with a different approachand found out the game concept is much deeper that I thought.The concept of the game is to make wise decisions for your,where you have to balance food and production in the beggining and later on warfare and trade are added.Great game in general looking at the given price and content ratio.Try it and enjoy.

Worth the money I guess, if you are not frustrated by low to no replayability once you finished it.

26034800.review: РАБАНЫ, Я СЕГОДНЯ ШЁЛ КОРОЧЕ ПО ПУСТЫНЕ И УВИДЕЛ БЕДУИНА В МАЙКЕ "МОЛЮСЬ СЕТУ", НУ Я ПОДСКОЧИЛ И РЕЗКО ПЕРEEБАЛ ЕМУ В ЩЩИ С ВЕРТУШКИ И ПОЯСНИЛ ЕГО КРИКОМ "НЕ ЛЮБЛЮ СОБАК", ПОТОМУ ЧТО Я УГОРЕЛ ПО ХОРУ, РАБАНЫ ДУХ СТАРОЙ ШКОЛЫ ЖИВЁТ ТОЛЬКО В ПИРАМИДАХ, ГДЕ ЕБАШАТСЯ ПО ХАРДКОРУ, ГДЕ РАБАНЫ ЖИВУТ ЭНЕРГИЕЙ, МОЛОДОСТЬЮ И EБУТ СИСТЕМУ В РОТ! 26034222.review:

Es fühlt sich mehr wie die bekannte Civilization-Reihe an, bietet jedoch im Vergleich zu diesem nur einen geringen Wiederspielwert da die Karte immer die gleiche bleibt.

Das Punktesystem aus den alten Teilen wurde übernommen und bietet eine spannende Challenge, es gibt ausserdem Karten, mit welchen man seine Nation zu Beginn des Spieler customizen kann.

Für den Preis von 9.00 eine definitive Kaufempfehlung

26013348.developer_response:
Hi, thanks for the feedback, but it is strange that’s you review is negative after such a good word about the game. The game seems linear because it is based on the real history of Egypt. But now, almost any strategy game is linear: X–Com series gives only tactical freedom, in the rest, except for the side missions, it is linear. Tropico series – the same linear missions. Almost any strategic series are linear today.

We made a historical game and it has rails - the history of Pre-Dynastic Egypt. The trials are real historical milestones, but players are free to choose different tactics for strategic development to achieve different goals. So, we don't differ from other strategy games in our approach.

Please try the new game balance in 1.0.1 update and we will be happy if you will change your mind.

26005506.review:
The game requires a decent level of strategy, and is quite fun, but in its current state does not have much replay-ability, at least for me. For the price I paid (US$8), I am quite happy with my purchase, but am disappointed that I won't be playing much more of it. 

EDIT: Having replayed this game since a MAJOR UPDATE, many of the issues I had detailed below have been fixed. 


My experiences and criticisms are set out below:

I found myself identifying with many of the challenges faced by another reviewer (Saint Ceo de la Vegas), where in both my playthorughs, I started the game on easy, and in that setting I found the challenges within the "settlement screen" difficult, but achievable. I managed to unite my region, amass (what I thought was) a substantial army, was constructing buildings quickly and in line with technological advances. 

However, as soon the game shifted to an Egypt-wide emphasis ("fog of war map"), any progress I had made seemed woefully limited. The challenges to build, explore, unite and fight cities were just too substantial. 

I completely shifted all production to military in order to attempt to build an army that could come close to taking on Seth (or at least defend myself against Seth, which I was able to do), but still couldn't come close to having enough soldiers for this. I was able to unite 4 or 5 tribes at this level, build a 3k + strong army, but I never felt in a position to even confront the smallest Seth settlement. 

I was totally unable to build several of the special tombs due to lack of exploration at this point (despite having more than enough workers and resources) ... it just came down to timing and exploration, I wasn't fast enough and the game punished me for it, this can be good and bad. 

In this case however, I felt that even if I had sped up my style of play and succeeded in building the tombs, I wouldn't have been able to challenge Seth militarily anyway, and this was confirmed in my second playthough.

I want to qualify this review by saying I enjoyed the game and would recommend it. 

In reaction to the developer: I do not think a special mode needs to be created to make the game "much easier". I'd suggest within the current easy mode, just reduce scouting times, and reduce the size of a few of the enemy armies (or make building armies faster/easier... for instance instead of +6 soldiers on a site, make it +12, or whatever).

25999971.review:
The big potential pitfall is if you go into this looking for a "heavier" game. The decisions available at any give time are fairly limited, the basic starting situation is roughly the same with every playthrough, and a big part of the game is about having gathered the proper resources for events that occur at set times. These things make this more of a strategy-puzzle game, and if that's not something you enjoy you're going to be in for a nasty surprise when you start up your second playthrough.

Other than that caveat, the only real complaint I have is the inability to turn off the tutorials, but those are unobtrusive enough. Overall, this is a really solid game.

25999514.review:
One of the best games I've played recently, it has a very good money-to-value ratio. 

It reminds me of Pharaoh and Cleopatra, but on an entirely different scale - you start as a small tribe of several hunter-gatherers and gradually you shift to a more advanced society, creating first religions, alphabets, assimilating or killing other tribes - this is a wonderful experience for anyone who likes pre-civiliazation era. 

Once your settlement is large enough, you will proceed to create a proto-state and then a true state. This requires a lot of skill and cunning, and diplomacy and very careful resource allocation is a must. 

One word of advice - expand north, FAST, or else you're screwed. Ignore your enemies and they will grow in numbers in no time.


Some cons now:
1. The replayability value is lower because there is no randomly generated map - you will start in the same place, with the same resources and the same tribes. Not exactly the best feature.
2. Personally, I'd like to see some more diplomatic options - marriages, alliances, little more detail about how faith is spread etc.


Despite the cons, I can heartily recommend it. It is a very good game, and has a good price too.

25993014.review:
My first 30 minutes or so I enjoyed the game - I thought it was relaxing and fun.  That changed.

My scores on my games were:  0/35, -1/35, -1/35, 0/35, -0/35  - I only completed all the way to the end twice. THAT's on EASY? setting. You gotta be f ing kidding me?  So I played 6 hours. I tried the easiest setting supposedly. The fastest game was FIVE turns where mysteriously my two guys just disappeared?! The first guy or the second guy ALWAYS seems to disappear on turn 4 for some reason? EVERY time.  Your guy disappears on turn 4.  (WTF?)

The game crushes you on 'easy' setting, I have no idea what it does on harder settings ( that makes it not fun for me, makes me give the game a bad review, tell my friends not to buy it, and post negative in the forums).  

I found it to be unrealistic to 'win' the different levels / challenges. I tried expanding fast, didn't work. I tried expanding slow to build up resources, didn't work as the game just cascades down on you that you are behind to build a temple or whatever because you have been trying to gather resources – or else the game just attacks you with superior numbers.

I have like 400 guys and get crushed by an army of over 1000 because I haven't even discovered the other tribes I need.  When I do find the tribes to bolster my army, I don't have enough little hammer production to give them gifts and 'Unite' in time.   One time I actually DID have more soldiers than the attacking army (barely), but they won because they 'flanked' me?  Where do I learn flanking, or anti-flanking, or anything I need?  Nowhere, game over, city defeated.

The game tells you that I have so many turns to build something and I haven't even explored the North of the city I need to progress the discoveries I need.  There's an automatic blockade, and so I have to stop everything to research and research to get the workaround. 

BOTH times I got to the '15 turns to end of game' warning I was NOWHERE near uncovering the fog of war map, let alone converting the tribes I need!  So in 15 turns I have to uncover the rest of the map, and fight or convert like 7 cities?  Really?  I think the BEST I got was ONE city on the big map converted before getting the 15 turn warning.

The biggest army I amassed by end game was 1.1K, meanwhile Seth had one city with 7K, a couple with 3K, and more... really?  This is EASY?  This is FUN?

Honestly, did you have ANYone test this thing out that is a casual gamer that doesn't know the code?  ... or was I it?  Did I have to buy the f ing game to test it for you and give you game play feedback?  Hey, it's not expensive, so thumbs up there, BUT if all it does is end up pizzing me off, then it doesn't matter, does it?

25971180.review:
This game is like a puzzle.  You keep coming back to try that one new strategy.  Food/Production/Army/Culture/Authority.  All five resources that need to be balanced.  And then there's whether you scout new territory or you trade with that city or you attack that city or you join that city.  Then you chose which cult to honor.

There's a lot of strategic choices that add up and then you learn when events happen and how to prepare for them.  Don't be fooled into thinking this is a simple game.  This is like a complex board game with a lot of potential tactical decisions.

It is a little luck dependent.  If you get 1 food/2production square early can definitely shape your progress.  But you can always save/reload scum.

The developer is committed to excellence.

If you want a board game like experience that rewards tactical thinking and makes you keep coming back to try one new strategy buy this game.

One more round -> one more playthrough

The principle of  Pre-Civilizazion: Marble Age was taken and advanced into a worthy successor.

Worth the 10 bucks; although you might want to give its predecessor (ranging between 1-5€)  a shot to see if this type of game suits you.

Only one thing to critisize: unlike its predecessor this game does not feature Steam-Achievements.

39501880.review:
Отличная игра. Геймплей простой и понятный, но всякие испытания постоянно вынуждают как-то шевелиться, перераспределять ресурсы и прочее, за кажущейся простотой скрывается куча разных тактических сложностей.
Отличная стилистика, в целом очень атмосферно, действительно ощущается прогресс племени. Очень хочется увидеть подобные игры и про другие нации.

39514241.review: Пиздос, огромный респект разработчикам этой игры! Вроде бы и простенькая стратегия, а сколько воспоминаний, когда по детству играл в первую "Колонизацию" и первые "Цивилизации". Давно мечтал, именно о чём-то похожем на старые-добрые "цивы" и мои тайные помыслы услышали. Побольше игр по тематике истории древних государств лейте.
